questions.text: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of pain and swelling below her right eye for the past 3 days. She has also had excessive watering from her eyes during this period. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows erythema, tenderness, warmth, and swelling below the medial canthus of the right eye. There is purulent discharge from the lower lacrimal punctum on palpation of the swelling. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. The discharge is sent for cultures. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) is often indicated in patients who develop acute (or chronic) dacryocystitis, since the underlying cause is usually a nasolacrimal duct obstruction. However, DCR should be deferred until the active infection has subsided. Because this patient has features of active infection (erythema, warmth, purulent discharge from the lower punctum), DCR is not indicated at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

An obstructed nasolacrimal duct (NLD) is often the underlying cause of dacryocystitis. Lacrimal sac massage is effective in the management of congenital dacryostenosis, as the obstruction is caused by a persistent mucosal fold within the NLD. However, acquired dacryocystitis, which is often due to concretions, postinflammatory stenosis, or granulomatous diseases, cannot be treated with lacrimal sac massage.

C) INCORRECT:

Empirical IV ceftriaxone is indicated in patients with acute dacryocystitis involving systemic symptoms (i.e., fever) or complications (e.g., orbital cellulitis, cavernous sinus thrombosis). Clinical features of orbital cellulitis include exophthalmos, ophthalmoplegia, and diplopia, while those of cavernous sinus thrombosis include headache, periorbital edema, proptosis, and third, fourth, fifth, and/or sixth cranial nerve palsies.

D) CORRECT:

Acute dacryocystitis is most commonly caused by gram-positive cocci (staphylococci, streptococci). Oral antibiotics with gram-positive coverage, such as amoxicillin-clavulanate, would be the first-line empirical therapy in a patient with mild to moderate acute dacryocystitis. As this patient has no features of severe infection, i.e., fever or features of orbital cellulitis (restricted, painful eye movement or diplopia), oral antibiotics are an appropriate treatment option. Warm compresses and NSAIDs are also used to decrease pain and inflammation.
Image Description:

Right eye of a 54-year-old male patient

A solid and immobile mass can be seen in the right fossa lacrimalis. There is no discharge of pus or other secretions.

These findings are typical of dacryocystitis, which can result from chronic inflammation of the lacrimal sac and/or chronic stenosis of the tear duct.

E) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the orbit might be indicated for suspected orbital cellulitis and would show inflammatory stranding of the orbital fat and edema of the extraocular muscles. Patients with orbital cellulitis typically have a fever, exophthalmos, ophthalmoplegia, and diplopia.
questions.hint: Pain, erythema, and swelling below the medial canthus of the right eye, along with purulent discharge from the lacrimal punctum, are consistent with acute dacryocystitis.

questions.text:
A 4-month-old boy is brought in by his parents for concerns about recurrent conjunctivitis. They have taken him to urgent care for mucopurulent eye discharge three times in the 2 months since he started day care, and on each of these occasions, he received a 3-day course of antibiotic eye ointment. They note that he has had tearing from his right eye since the first month of life.
On examination, the patient is afebrile, with unremarkable vital signs. He has mild rhinorrhea and a cough but is breathing comfortably. He has conjugate extraocular movements, and his pupils are equally round and reactive to light. The right eye has tearing with mild conjunctival injection and mucopurulent discharge along the eyelids. A firm, cystic mass with a slight bluish tint is apparent just below the medial canthus of the right eye. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.
What is the most appropriate next step for this infant?

choices.text: Application of warm compresses twice daily for one week
Evaluation for corneal trauma with fluorescein dye
Instruction for the parents about nasolacrimal duct massage
Bacterial culture of the ocular discharge

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Supportive care, such as warm compresses, would be appropriate for viral conjunctivitis or a hordeolum, but this patient's presentation is not consistent with either of these diagnoses. Although viral conjunctivitis is common in children, particularly in the day care setting, it would not be associated with a firm, cystic mass below the eye — nor would a hordeolum, which appears as an erythematous mass along the lash line.

B) INCORRECT:

Evaluation for a corneal abrasion with fluorescein dye is not necessary in this patient, given the chronic nature of her tearing. Corneal abrasions in infants usually occur as a result of a scratch by a fingernail and typically manifest with acute onset of tearing and irritability.

C) INCORRECT:

Most cases of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction resolve within the first 12 months of life, and the parents can be instructed in nasolacrimal duct massage and lid hygiene. However, when a dacryocystocele is suspected (as in this case), urgent referral to an ophthalmologist is warranted.

D) CORRECT:

This patient’s history and clinical presentation suggest congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction, with concern for a dacryocystocele (or mucocele).

Congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction is characterized by excessive tearing (starting in the first few weeks of life), recurrent conjunctivitis, excoriation around the eye, and stickiness of the eyelashes after sleep. Untreated conjunctivitis in infants with this condition can develop into more-severe infections, such as blepharitis, dacryocystitis, and (if uncontrolled) orbital cellulitis.

Most cases of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction resolve within the first 12 months of life, and the parents can be instructed in nasolacrimal duct massage and lid hygiene. However, when a dacryocystocele is suspected (as in this case), urgent referral to an ophthalmologist is warranted. Dacryocystoceles occur when there is both proximal and distal obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct system; this cystic expansion can extend into the nose, causing respiratory distress. Dacryocystoceles occur in less than 1% of cases of nasolacrimal duct obstruction but require urgent attention.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an infant with persistent excessive tearing, recurrent conjunctivitis, and a firm, cystic mass below the medial canthus is congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction with concern for a dacryocystocele.

E) INCORRECT:

Bacterial culture of the ocular discharge would be appropriate for ophthalmia neonatorum, a specific type of conjunctivitis often caused by gonorrhea or chlamydia. However, this condition is apparent within the first month of life. Gonococcal conjunctivitis typically manifests with hyperpurulent discharge in the first 2 to 5 days of life, although erythromycin prophylaxis may cause a delay. This patient requires referral, independent of any culture results.

questions.text:
A 3-month-old boy presents with onset of progressive right lower eyelid and nasal hyperemic swelling over the past 24 hours (figure). There is some mucopurulent discharge coming from the eye. The conjunctiva is white and quiet, and there is full ocular motility. The upper eyelid has minimal involvement. There are no vesicles or pustules noted around the eye.
On further questioning, the mother notes that the boy has had some eyelid crusting and occasional discharge from the eye since birth. It is usually worse in the morning, and the mother has needed to regularly wipe the drainage away with a clean tissue.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iritis is inflammation within the anterior chamber of the eye. Affected patients report photophobia, and there can be slight perilimbal hyperemia. The eyelid and conjunctiva are not involved. Although iritis can be caused by an infectious process, it is more typically related to an underlying autoimmune condition, especially juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Orbital cellulitis is an infection of the eye socket behind the orbital septum. It most commonly occurs with the acute spread of infection from the ethmoid or frontal sinuses. Signs of orbital infection include limited eye movements, conjunctival hyperemia, and proptosis. Orbital cellulitis typically affects older children and adolescents; it is less common in infants because of their immaturely developed sinuses. Dacryocystitis can also have a preseptal component, as in this case, but this is differentiated from orbital involvement by inflammation limited to the external structures of the eye.

C) INCORRECT:

There is no evidence that this child has a viral keratoconjunctivitis, which typically manifests in the neonatal period as a complication of perinatally acquired herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. Presentation would include conjunctivitis and tearing of the eye and can involve periorbital swelling. Infants with perinatally acquired HSV who have localized skin, eye, and mouth disease may have lesions in all or some of these areas, and the virus can be cultured from mucous membranes and directly from lesions.

D) INCORRECT:

Neonatal conjunctivitis occurs within the first week of life and can be caused by Neisseria gonorrhea or Chlamydia. Affected patients present with mucopurulent discharge and conjunctival injection, which is not present on this infant’s examination.

E) CORRECT:

Dacryocystitis is an inflammation and infection of the lacrimal sac resulting from obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct and secondary backup of tears. In infants, the obstruction typically occurs at the Hasner valve, located in the nose at the distal end of the nasolacrimal duct. Excess tearing often occurs from birth, with the addition of crusting of the lashes and a mucopurulent discharge in some cases. Staphylococcus aureus, group B streptococci, Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Haemophilus influenzae can then colonize the nondraining nasolacrimal sac and cause a secondary inflammation and infection. This can then extend temporally to involve the lower eyelid and face.

Treatment of dacryocystitis includes systemic antibiotics. Intravenous antibiotics are required if there is evidence of infection extending into the orbit. Topical antibiotic drops can also be used to sterilize the sac. Once the infection is cleared, more definitive treatment might be required. Although the duct opens spontaneously by one year of age in 90% of children, early nasolacrimal-duct probing is indicated if a patient has frequent infections or significant, persistent excess tearing and mucopurulent discharge from the eye.

Key learning point: In infants, dacryocystitis can manifest with signs and symptoms similar to those of conjunctivitis, but dacryocystitis is the more common diagnosis.

questions.text: A 3-month-old boy presents with onset of progressive right lower eyelid and nasal hyperemic swelling over the past 24 hours. The conjunctiva is white and there is full ocular motility. The patient has had some eyelid crusting and occasional discharge from the eye since birth. Physical examination shows the findings in the photograph. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iritis is inflammation within the anterior chamber of the eye. Affected patients report photophobia, and there can be slight perilimbal hyperemia. The eyelid and conjunctiva are not involved. Although iritis can be caused by an infectious process, it is more typically related to an underlying autoimmune condition, especially juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

Orbital cellulitis is an infection of the eye socket behind the orbital septum. It most commonly occurs with the acute spread of infection from the ethmoid or frontal sinuses. Signs of orbital infection include limited eye movements, conjunctival hyperemia, and proptosis. Orbital cellulitis typically affects older children and adolescents; it is less common in infants because of their immaturely developed sinuses.

C) INCORRECT:

There is no evidence that this child has a viral keratoconjunctivitis, which typically manifests in the neonatal period as a complication of perinatally acquired herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. E) CORRECT:

In infants, the obstruction typically occurs at the Hasner valve, located in the nose at the distal end of the nasolacrimal duct. Excess tearing often occurs from birth, with the addition of crusting of the lashes and a mucopurulent discharge in some cases. Staphylococcus aureus, group B streptococcus , Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Haemophilus influenza e can then colonize the nondraining nasolacrimal sac and cause a secondary inflammation and infection. This can then extend temporally to involve the lower eyelid and face.

Treatment of dacryocystitis includes systemic antibiotics. Intravenous antibiotics are required if there is evidence of infection extending into the orbit. Topical antibiotic drops can also be used to sterilize the sac. Once the infection is cleared, more definitive treatment might be required. Although the duct opens spontaneously by one year of age in 90% of children, early nasolacrimal-duct probing is indicated if a patient has frequent infections or significant, persistent excess tearing and mucopurulent discharge from the eye.

Key learning point: In infants, dacryocystitis can manifest with signs and symptoms similar to those of conjunctivitis, but dacryocystitis is the more common diagnosis.

questions.text: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the office by his parents because of constant tearing from the right eye since the first month of life. He also frequently has crusting around the right eye in the morning. There is no history of trauma. He was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. The patient received routine postpartum care. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows conjugate extraocular movements. His pupils are equally round and reactive to light. The right eye has tearing with mild redness along the lower eyelid. Palpation on the medial canthus of the right eye causes mucoid discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the clinician?

choices.text: Recommend lid hygiene and warm compresses
Obtain ocular culture and gram stain

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dacryocystorhinostomy is a surgical procedure that creates a direct connection between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity, enabling unobstructed tear drainage. This intervention is typically reserved for dacryostenosis that does not respond to other treatments.

B) INCORRECT:

Supportive therapy with lid hygiene and warm compresses is appropriate for viral conjunctivitis, blepharitis, or hordeolum. While crusting around the eye and watery discharge can occur in these conditions, this patient's presentation is consistent with dacryostenosis, which requires a different treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical erythromycin is an appropriate treatment for bacterial conjunctivitis, which manifests with erythematous conjunctivae and purulent discharge. However, this patient's presentation is consistent with dacryostenosis, which requires a different treatment.

D) CORRECT:

Lacrimal sac massage is the first-line treatment for congenital dacryostenosis, which is typically caused by obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct at the valve of Hasner. Diagnosis is clinical, but lacrimal syringing may be used if there is diagnostic uncertainty. Caregivers should apply gentle downward pressure to the nasolacrimal duct below the medial canthus of the eye, facilitating the rupture of the obstructing valve. This procedure should be repeated 3–4 times daily until symptoms resolve. Most cases resolve within 6 months of age with conservative management. Dilation or stenting of the duct may be performed to treat congenital dacryostenosis that does not improve with lacrimal sac massage.
Image Description:

Illustration depicting the technique of lacrimal sac massage for congenital dacryostenosis

Gentle pressure is applied to the region below the medial canthus of the eye in a downward direction in order to increase the pressure within the nasolacrimal duct and cause the obstructing valve of Hasner to rupture.
This process should be repeated 3–4 times per day.

Lacrimal sac massage is the first-line of treatment for congenital dacryostenosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Bacterial culture of the ocular discharge is appropriate for neonatal conjunctivitis, which is often caused by Neisseria gonorrhea or Chlamydia trachomatis. Neonatal conjunctivitis typically manifests < 4 weeks of age and causes conjunctival injection, swollen eyelids and, if left untreated, blindness and systemic infection. However, this 3-month-old patient received routine postnatal care, and his presentation is consistent with dacryostenosis, which requires a different treatment.
Image Description:

The eyelids are swollen, with purulent exudate forming crusts around them. Below the crusts there may be a large reservoir of pus. Special care should be taken and safety goggles should be worn when examining the eyes.
questions.hint: Chronic tearing since infancy, mild eyelid redness, and mucoid discharge elicited by palpation of the medial canthus are consistent with congenital dacryostenosis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 3-month-old boy whose parents report progressive swelling and redness of the right lower eyelid and nasal area over the past 24 hours. The conjunctiva is white and ocular motility is full. Since birth, he has had intermittent eyelid crusting and occasional eye discharge. Physical examination reveals the findings shown in the photograph. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iritis is inflammation within the anterior chamber of the eye. Affected patients report photophobia, and there can be slight perilimbal hyperemia. The eyelid and conjunctiva are not involved. Although iritis can be caused by an infectious process, it is more typically related to an underlying autoimmune condition, especially juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Orbital cellulitis is an infection of the eye socket behind the orbital septum. It most commonly occurs with the acute spread of infection from the ethmoid or frontal sinuses. Signs of orbital infection include limited eye movements, conjunctival hyperemia, and proptosis. Orbital cellulitis typically affects older children and adolescents; it is less common in infants because of their immaturely developed sinuses.

C) INCORRECT:

Neonatal conjunctivitis occurs within the first week of life and can be caused by Neisseria gonorrhea or Chlamydia. Affected patients present with mucopurulent discharge and conjunctival injection, which is not present on this infant’s examination.

D) INCORRECT:

There is no evidence that this child has a viral keratoconjunctivitis, which typically manifests in the neonatal period as a complication of perinatally acquired herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection. Presentation would include conjunctivitis and tearing of the eye and can involve periorbital swelling. Infants with perinatally acquired HSV who have localized skin, eye, and mouth disease may have lesions in all or some of these areas, and the virus can be cultured from mucous membranes and directly from lesions.

E) CORRECT:

Dacryocystitis is an inflammation and infection of the lacrimal sac resulting from obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct and secondary backup of tears. In infants, the obstruction typically occurs at the Hasner valve, located in the nose at the distal end of the nasolacrimal duct. Excess tearing often occurs from birth, with the addition of crusting of the lashes and a mucopurulent discharge in some cases. Staphylococcus aureus, group B streptococcus , Streptococcus pneumoniae, and Haemophilus influenza e can then colonize the nondraining nasolacrimal sac and cause a secondary inflammation and infection. This can then extend temporally to involve the lower eyelid and face.

Treatment of dacryocystitis includes systemic antibiotics. Intravenous antibiotics are required if there is evidence of infection extending into the orbit. Topical antibiotic drops can also be used to sterilize the sac. Once the infection is cleared, more definitive treatment might be required. Although the duct opens spontaneously by one year of age in 90% of children, early nasolacrimal-duct probing is indicated if a patient has frequent infections or significant, persistent excess tearing and mucopurulent discharge from the eye.

Key learning point: In infants, dacryocystitis can manifest with signs and symptoms similar to those of conjunctivitis, but dacryocystitis is the more common diagnosis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 3-month-old boy brought to your clinic by his parents because of constant tearing from his right eye since the first month of life. His parents also report frequent crusting around the right eye in the morning. There is no history of trauma. He was born at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery, and received routine postpartum care. Vital signs are normal. On examination, he has conjugate extraocular movements and his pupils are equally round and reactive to light. The right eye shows tearing with mild redness along the lower eyelid. Palpation of the medial canthus of the right eye produces mucoid discharge. Which one of the following is the most appropriate action?

choices.text: Obtain ocular culture and gram stain.
Recommend lid hygiene and warm compresses.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dacryocystorhinostomy is a surgical procedure that creates a direct connection between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity, enabling unobstructed tear drainage. This intervention is typically reserved for dacryostenosis that does not respond to other treatments.

B) CORRECT:

Lacrimal sac massage is the first-line treatment for congenital dacryostenosis, which is typically caused by obstruction of the nasolacrimal duct at the valve of Hasner. Diagnosis is clinical, but lacrimal syringing may be used if there is diagnostic uncertainty. Caregivers should apply gentle downward pressure to the nasolacrimal duct below the medial canthus of the eye, facilitating the rupture of the obstructing valve. This procedure should be repeated 3–4 times daily until symptoms resolve. Most cases resolve within 6 months of age with conservative management. Dilation or stenting of the duct may be performed to treat congenital dacryostenosis that does not improve with lacrimal sac massage.

Key learning point: Lacrimal sac massage is the first-line treatment for congenital dacryostenosis, as most cases resolve spontaneously with conservative management by 6 months of age.
Image Description:

Illustration depicting the technique of lacrimal sac massage for congenital dacryostenosis

Gentle pressure is applied to the region below the medial canthus of the eye in a downward direction in order to increase the pressure within the nasolacrimal duct and cause the obstructing valve of Hasner to rupture.
This process should be repeated 3–4 times per day.

Lacrimal sac massage is the first-line of treatment for congenital dacryostenosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Bacterial culture of the ocular discharge is appropriate for neonatal conjunctivitis, which is often caused by Neisseria gonorrhea or Chlamydia trachomatis. Neonatal conjunctivitis typically manifests < 4 weeks of age and causes conjunctival injection, swollen eyelids and, if left untreated, blindness and systemic infection. However, this 3-month-old patient received routine postnatal care, and his presentation is consistent with dacryostenosis, which requires a different treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical erythromycin is an appropriate treatment for bacterial conjunctivitis, which manifests with erythematous conjunctivae and purulent discharge. However, this patient's presentation is consistent with dacryostenosis, which requires a different treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Supportive therapy with lid hygiene and warm compresses is appropriate for viral conjunctivitis, blepharitis, or hordeolum. While crusting around the eye and watery discharge can occur in these conditions, this patient's presentation is consistent with dacryostenosis, which requires a different treatment.
questions.hint: Chronic tearing since infancy, mild eyelid redness, and mucoid discharge elicited by palpation of the medial canthus are consistent with congenital dacryostenosis.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with diabetes presents with a 3-day history of progressive swelling and tenderness near the inner corner of his right eye. He tried over-the-counter antibiotic eye drops without improvement. Examination findings are shown. A small amount of purulent discharge is expressed from the punctum with gentle pressure. His temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F). What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Topical ciprofloxacin and follow-up in 48 hours
Warm compresses and follow-up in 24-48 hours
CT scan of the orbits with contrast

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Acute dacryocystitis is a bacterial infection of the lacrimal sac requiring systemic antibiotic therapy. Oral clindamycin provides good coverage against typical pathogens including streptococci and staphylococci. Ophthalmologic referral is important for specialized management and to address the underlying nasolacrimal duct obstruction once the acute infection resolves.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics are typically ineffective for treating dacryocystitis. An alternative step in management is more appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Nasolacrimal duct probing is contraindicated in patients with acute dacryocystitis due to the risk of spreading bacteria to surrounding tissue. Probing should only be considered after the acute infection has been adequately treated with antibiotics.

D) INCORRECT:

While warm compresses can provide symptomatic relief and may help with drainage, they are insufficient as primary treatment for acute dacryocystitis. This patient's presentation of purulent discharge, swelling, and fever indicates a bacterial infection requiring antibiotic therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

While urgent CT of the orbits would be indicated if there were red flags of orbital extension (e.g., proptosis, decreased visual acuity, or ophthalmoplegia), CT is not routinely indicated for uncomplicated acute dacryocystitis.
